jyoshu

Why isn't news like this being reported more?
 
 http://hosted.ap.org/dynamic/stories/I/IRAQ_RAIDS?SITE=7219&SECTION=HOME&TEMPLATE=DEFAULT&CTIME=2006-06-15-08-25-20
 
 Everytime a person is killed or injured in Iraq, it makes CNN, but 104 insurgents are killed in subsequent attacks after Zarqawi and we never even hear about it??? (other than this rare, tiny, buried and obscure AP piece.)
 
 I don't understand why more people aren't frustrated with the media coverage for this war. It's SO slanted in favor of the anti-war movement, it's ridiculous. Something's wrong when every time someone is killed it big news, but everyday victories are never reported.
 
 I have a cousin who just returned from a tour of duty in Iraq, and after being over there awhile, he told his family don't even bother watching CNN because it's such an inaccurate and incomplete picture.

Wiz
the American news media machine is completely self serving. they have no interest in reporting the news unless they put their spin on it.
daewoo

This is an inaccurate number. Recent numbers show somewhere between 12,000-20,000 total. that is far less than your 6.7 million.
 
 http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Iraqi_insurgency

 In reality, my figures are probably low as well. 
 
 http://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/main.jhtml?xml=/news/2005/10/23/wirq23.xml&sSheet=/portal/2005/10/23/ixportaltop.html
 
 
The poll, undertaken for the Ministry of Defence and seen by The Sunday Telegraph, shows that up to 65 per cent of Iraqi citizens support attacks and fewer than one per cent think Allied military involvement is helping to improve security in their country.

 
 At the time my numbers were compiled, only about 45% of Iraqis supported attacks. If that number has grown to 65%, it stands to reason that the number of active insurgents is likely higher.
daewoo

Well gee, it seems to be anything OTHER than a "non-event" when 1 (one) U.S. serviceperson's death makes the national news every time. It's not that U.S. casualties shouldn't make the news. It's that some of us would like some balance in terms for reporting successes as well.

 
 US causlties make the news becuase they are US casualties, though our military is careful to only regularly announce deaths, not injuries or serious injuries (which are also casualties).
 
 Do you really think that the war hawks want this kind of information floating around (194 dead). Any critical thinker ont he planet is going to look at the this and have seriosu problems with the math. How many billions did we spend to kill those 104 people?

Both of those estimates are pre saddam capture, an event that boosted the insurgency exponentially.

 At the time my numbers were compiled, only about 45% of Iraqis supported attacks. If that number has grown to 65%, it stands to reason that the number of active insurgents is likely higher.

Why isn't news like this being reported more?

 Everytime a person is killed or injured in Iraq, it makes CNN, but 104 insurgents are killed in subsequent attacks after Zarqawi and we never even hear about it??? (other than this rare, tiny, buried and obscure AP piece.)
 
 I don't understand why more people aren't frustrated with the media coverage for this war. It's SO slanted in favor of the anti-war movement, it's ridiculous. Something's wrong when every time someone is killed it big news, but everyday victories are never reported.
 
 I have a cousin who just returned from a tour of duty in Iraq, and after being over there awhile, he told his family don't even bother watching CNN because it's such an inaccurate and incomplete picture.

Actually no they were not. Furthermore, you article only talks about how Iraqis don't think we are helping anything...this is no shocker.

 
 The poll, undertaken for the Ministry of Defence and seen by The Sunday Telegraph, shows that up to 65 per cent of Iraqi citizens support attacks and fewer than one per cent think Allied military involvement is helping to improve security in their country.

The poll, undertaken for the Ministry of Defence and seen by The Sunday Telegraph, shows that up to 65 per cent of Iraqi citizens support attacks and fewer than one per cent think Allied military involvement is helping to improve security in their country.

 I support the local baseball team but that doesn't make me a player on the team
jyoshu

US causlties make the news becuase they are US casualties, though our military is careful to only regularly announce deaths, not injuries or serious injuries (which are also casualties).

 
 Since when do US casualties in terms of deaths make the new every time, much less what you'd apparently like to see? (every grazed bullet, sprained ankle, etc.!) Actually, this is the first war we've ever had where nearly every casualty is reported as a news event. Even the Vietnam was (which was FAR worse in terms of casualties) didn't have such one-sided reporting.
 
 
Any critical thinker ont he planet is going to look at the this and have seriosu problems with the math. How many billions did we spend to kill those 104 people?

 
 Why do you seem to always use the economical aspect of the war as a fallback everytime you find yourself in a discussion about Iraq that you can't defend very well? We're not even talking about the financial impact--we're talking about biased and unbalanced news coming out of Iraq.
jyoshu

I find it baffling that you think that not reporting deaths of insurgents shows an anti-war slant. This shows a deep lack of understanding of many of the people who are anti-war.

 
 In what way? And why should we not be hearing about EVERYTHING that's happening?
Liminus

All I can say is watch UK Channel 4 news; you will not get better mainstream coverage (I don't know how easy it is to get hold of in the states but it must be on cable somewhere) and read sources like The Independent (UK), Le Monde (France) and Al-Jazeera (yes, Al-Jazeera) and the vast number of inependent internet news sources.
 
 If you don't, and you rely on US news sources you are simply being uniformed and/or misinformed. Simple as.
 
 The important thing is to read many different sources, weigh up the various different viewpoints given and MAKE YOUR OWN MIND UP rather than believing what you hear from standard sources. That's all I can say.
 
 The news from Iraq is no more slanted than any other news if you only rely on a limited number of sources.
Liminus

Since when do US casualties in terms of deaths make the new every time, much less what you'd apparently like to see? (every grazed bullet, sprained ankle, etc.!)

 
 Sine the US announced that "We don't do body counts".Counting the civilian cost in Iraq
 
 
Actually, this is the first war we've ever had where nearly every casualty is reported as a news event. Even the Vietnam was (which was FAR worse in terms of casualties) didn't have such one-sided reporting.

 
 Elaboration? Facts/links? I only ask because I wasn't alive during this period and have no idea...
 
 
Why do you seem to always use the economical aspect of the war as a fallback everytime you find yourself in a discussion about Iraq that you can't defend very well? We're not even talking about the financial impact--we're talking about biased and unbalanced news coming out of Iraq.

 
 But the financial aspect is probably the most important - that's how Bin Laden hopes to beat the West just as the West beat Russia in the Cold "War".
 
 As for biased news, what I have seen of US news coverage of Iraq makes me sick in terms of its lack of any kind of respect for Life, Liberty, Justice, etc, etc
jyoshu

Sine the US announced that "We don't do body counts".

 
 Hah! They don't have to--the media does it for them. But again, I'd have no problem with it if they'd just give both sides of it.
 
 
Elaboration? Facts/links? I only ask because I wasn't alive during this period and have no idea...

 
 I certainly don't remember news reports every single night everytime a platoon got shot up. 
 
 
But the financial aspect is probably the most important - that's how Bin Laden hopes to beat the West just as the West beat Russia in the Cold "War".

 
 It may be, but that's not what my comments were about. It's a different issue than reporting imbalance.

In what way?

 Because people who are truly anti-war believe deaths on all sides are bad things. If someone who was anti-war was trying to put a message out in the news, they would be discussing every death on all sides.
 
And why should we not be hearing about EVERYTHING that's happening?

 You seem to be trasplanting your discussion with daewoo to me. I said nothing of the sort.
jyoshu

Because people who are truly anti-war believe deaths on all sides are bad things. If someone who was anti-war was trying to put a message out in the news, they would be discussing every death on all sides.

 
 Then maybe it's not that the press is trying to pander to the anti-war movement, but rather they're just doing sloppy reporting.
daewoo

Since when do US casualties in terms of deaths make the new every time, much less what you'd apparently like to see? (every grazed bullet, sprained ankle, etc.!) Actually, this is the first war we've ever had where nearly every casualty is reported as a news event. Even the Vietnam was (which was FAR worse in terms of casualties) didn't have such one-sided reporting.

Why do you seem to always use the economical aspect of the war as a fallback everytime you find yourself in a discussion about Iraq that you can't defend very well? We're not even talking about the financial impact--we're talking about biased and unbalanced news coming out of Iraq.

 
 I have no problem defending this. News agencies are going for ratings just like any other entertainment venue. People want to know about the casualties. End of story.
 
 Why do I use the economic aspects of the IRaq war? Becuase they are absolutly key on both the Iraq war and the war on terror. The war on terror is strictly an economic war. BL announced over 10 years ago that the war with the US would be just like the war with the soviets with the victory being in our economic demise. 
 
 In Iraq, we simply cannot afford the costs that would be associated with victory. At this point, another 5 years in Iraq at current expenditure level would crash the dollar and bankrupt the US. 
 
 Unfortunatly it seems that your average terrorist leader has a far greater understanding of US economics than most Americans. Already the deficits created in fighting these wars are driving the dollar down. We are now celebrating a current accuont deficit that just 5 years ago would have been unthinkable. I am surprised that BL has not given a "mission accomplished" speech. I guess he is just not into cheap theatrics.

Then maybe it's not that the press is trying to pander to the anti-war movement, but rather they're just doing sloppy reporting.

 Well, now that certainly wouldn't surprise me :)

The fundamental problem with all of our news networks is that they are driven by ratings. This system undermines the true goal of journalism which should be to report facts.

The media is not concerned about the good news. They are concerned about ratings and their agenda. 
 It is a known fact that the Vietnam war was lost due to the media. We didn't lose one battle in that country. 
 The terrorists know that they in fact cannot defeat our forces. They know that the only way they can win is by using the media to beat down the will of the American people. This is the same tactic that lost the Vietnam war. 
 The stories that the majority of Iraqis think that the attacks are justified are just that, stoires. Nothing more. They are lies propogated by people with an agenda. This same thinking caused many American last month to believe that Rove was about to be indicted. It has been since discovered that the man who reported this "scoop" is a former coke addict who hates the right.

 Many lies are being reported and the truth is not being given.

Well in another thread I said this but I'll say it again.
 
 In High School we had a teacher's son whom is in the rangers come and visit the class. He spoke about the war and mentioned that a British New crew had come to their section in Iraq and stayed for 3 days. No one died and there hadn't been any real fighting there for awhile. They left when they heard a bombing had taken place somewhere up north from where they were.
 
 Its more that the news crews are looking for ratings.
